title: Are students allowed to refuse corporal punishment? - Quora

response.answer_text: In practical terms, in most US public schools that still use corporal punishment, I’d say students can refuse. Forcing an uncooperative child or adolescent to submit would open the individuals involved to the possibility of both criminal charges and civil litigation. Even in the 1980s when I went to a Texas public school that made frequent use of the paddle, a student who refused was not held down. Refusal simply meant suspension. However, a disturbing case happened in San Antonio, Texas at a charter school in 2004. School staff used actual force to hold down a young woman, Jessica Serafin, who was over 18, and who, therefore, insisted she had the right to refuse corporal punishment. (Her mother had signed a consent form while Serafin was a minor.) Serafin suffered injuries during the paddling and tried to sue the school. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed her case, and the Supreme Court denied her case review. In its ruling, the Fifth Circuit essentially said that Serafin’s rights weren’t violated. [1] There are probably other cases in which a school forced submission. While rare, schools have denied students the right to refuse corporal punishment in the US, and federal courts have upheld their actions. Footnotes[1] Student Rights
